text: He drank some of the wine, became drunk, and lay naked inside his tent.
But those who did not pay attention to the word of the LORD left their servants and their livestock in the fields.
but the briskets and the right thigh he raised as an elevated offering before the LORD, as the LORD had commanded Moses.

If it happened the cloud remained there only from evening until morning, when the cloud rose in the morning, they would break camp. Whether the cloud lifted during the day or the night they would then break camp.
Then, taking the calf, the sinful object you had made, I burnt it and ground it down to powder as fine as dust, which I threw into the wadi that went down the mountainside.
Thus the leaders said to them, “Let them live, and become hewers of wood and drawers of water for the entire community.” So the community did as the leaders advised them.
Then Jotham fled and escaped to Beer, where he remained for fear of his brother Abimelech.
Saul replied: “Am I not a Benjaminite, from the smallest of the tribes of Israel, and is not my clan the least among the clans of the tribe of Benjamin? Why say such things to me?” The Meal.
those of their descendants who were left in the land and whom the Israelites had not been able to destroy under the ban—these Solomon conscripted as forced laborers, as they are to this day.

“Hitch up my chariot,” said Joram, and they hitched up his chariot. Then Joram, king of Israel, and Ahaziah, king of Judah, set out, each in his own chariot, to meet Jehu. They reached him near the plot of ground of Naboth the Jezreelite.
Zechariah, son of Meshelemiah, guarded the gate of the tent of meeting.
For the king had ships that went to Tarshish with the servants of Huram. Once every three years the fleet of Tarshish ships would come with a cargo of gold, silver, ivory, apes, and monkeys.
Forty years in the desert you sustained them: they did not want; Their garments did not become worn, and their feet did not swell.
He ordered them to celebrate every year both the fourteenth and the fifteenth of the month of Adar
“How the mighty one has fallen, the savior of Israel!”

Now that I am ill, I recall with affection your esteem and goodwill. On returning from the regions of Persia, I fell victim to a troublesome illness; so I thought it necessary to form plans for the general security of all.
I am innocent, but I cannot know it; I despise my life.
Strike them with terror, LORD; show the nations they are only human. Selah
Corpses shall fall like dung in the open field, Like sheaves behind the harvester, with no one to gather them.
I was still praying, when the man, Gabriel, whom I had seen in vision before, came to me in flight at the time of the evening offering.
She said to herself, “If only I can touch his cloak, I shall be cured.”
Then he questioned his father, “How long has this been happening to him?” He replied, “Since childhood.
He rebuked them and directed them not to tell this to anyone.
We do not know how he sees now, nor do we know who opened his eyes. Ask him, he is of age; he can speak for himself.”
All who heard him were astounded and said, “Is not this the man who in Jerusalem ravaged those who call upon this name, and came here expressly to take them back in chains to the chief priests?”
Or does not the potter have a right over the clay, to make out of the same lump one vessel for a noble purpose and another for an ignoble one?
To those outside the law I became like one outside the law—though I am not outside God's law but within the law of Christ—to win over those outside the law.
In the same way, he sprinkled also the tabernacle and all the vessels of worship with blood.
Nor did they repent of their murders, their magic potions, their unchastity, or their robberies.
